Notes: Wide pair. Nearly equal. Oriented NE to SW. Yellow or orange and blue. Beside double HR 1065.
Widely separated. Intense colours, gold and blue. Unrelated bright orange-red star opposite B.
Very dim partner, NNE.
Colourful pair, yellow and pale blue. Tight. May be called HR 1211 as opposed to HR 1212.
Dim star beyond secondary, further north. Colourless.
Very wide. Primary is orange or yellow. B is blue or red? B nearly due east.
Another dim companion. C is very close to B, 9" apart! C north of B.
Very faint and a long ways away. Looks like a field star. To the NE.
A and B bright. B NW of A. Very tight. Both look blue-white. A showcase pair for many.
C much dimmer and well away to the SW. Looks pale blue?
Wide pair. Yellow and deep blue. B to the SW. Lots of field stars.
Interesting triple. Very dim. Close to B. In a hockey stick shape. C south of B.
Fantastic colours. Gold and deep blue. Quite tight. To the NE.
90° to A and B. Very far away, 20 to 25 times!
Widely separated, very attractive. Primary is white, a little yellow. Next star medium blue.
Very similar, pale yellow. Easily separated at 145x. Near Iota Orionis and Messier 42.
Faint companion to the N.
The Trapezium in the middle of M42. Stunning. B is NNE of A. Both white. Some report diff. colours.
A, B, C, and D are all fairly easy. C is SE of A.
A, B, C, and D are all fairly easy. D is kitty-corner from and east of A.
E and F get harder. Need good seeing. E is between A and B (but not in-line).
And higher magnification. F is SE of C.
Bonus points!
Same colour, white. Extremely tight. Bright. B a tiny bit dimmer than A. SE of A.
At low power B is not round. B very tight to C. C slightly dimmer than B. SE of B.
Four or five times the AB sep., to the NE, a right angle to A-B-C. Very faint, needs averted.
Yellow and orange. Nice. Primary is a K2 star. Near Mu Lep. Shown as single star in PSA.
Colourful, unequal stars. Bright primary, yellow. Faint secondary, orange.
Faint distant companion to the N.
Appears as a little triangle of stars in finder. Yellow primary, yellow secondary. To the NE.
The tertiary star was orange. To the SE. Neat! In a rich field.
Dim. Orange-red. To the W.
In an obvious triangle. Awesome. Light yellow primary. B dim to the E. In a neat field.
Fairly bright star to N. A light yellow; B blue. At a 90° angle to A and B. Much brighter than B.
Use averted vision. Between C and A stars.
The Winter Albireo. Main star orangey. Companion is pale, sky blue. Wonderful sight.
A, B, and D obvious in a flattened triangle. Primary is white; secondary blue? Oriented SE to NW.
A, B, and D obvious in a flattened triangle. Bright. Well to the N.
To the west. Dim!
Equal, similar colours. Both white? Pleasing separation at 71x; tight at 54x. Many field stars.
Dim and distant. Nearly due N. Orange.
Great system. The BC pair was far away NE. Incredible orange and blue at low power.
Faint. Use high power. Visible at low power in good seeing. Colourless. 90° to AB line.
aka HR 2909. Cool! Car headlights. Nearly same brightness. Same light yellow colour.
To the N. Nearly equal colour. Yellow and blue. Nearly equal brightness. Not far from Messier 46.
Dim and distant. To the SW. White.
or Tegmine. At high power, not round, a figure-8. Almost in-line with C. Split at 391x in 2012.
Pleasing at 52x. Main pale yellow colour, companion hint of orange? To the NE.
Faint, well away to the E.
NNE, further away than D.
The faintest of all. East of the E star. aka TYC 01381-0323 1.
G is to the NW, at a right angle to E star, about the same distance that E was from A.
Yellow and white. In middle of a triangle. B was roughly north.
C was to the east, was dimmer than E. C looked red. Opposite D.
Dim. Opposite C.
Brighter than C. Blue. To the south.
The dimmest of all. Furthest out.
Sparse field. Colourful. Bright primary SE, secondary NW. Lovely. A great system. Yellow-blue.
C is red. Very dim. W of A. At apex of right-angle bend, so B due north of C and A due east.
Near ε and ζ. Faint pair. Easy split at 62x. Yellow and orange. NE.
Additional companion needs a bigger aperture. Beyond B star.
Pleasing warm yellow main star and pale orange companion. Widely separated at 110x.
"HR 3963 fun starhop from Alphard." Will need larger aperture for B star. East of the primary
Wide pair at 48x. Blue or blue-white and orange. Faint. Oriented to the W.
Slightly unequal intensities. Nice. Medium tight. Secondary orange and main yellow.
Wide pair. Easy in big 'scope. Yellow and pale blue. Very similar brightness, B very slightly dimmer.
Bright stars. B SE. Easy split, tighter than Tau AB. West of Tau Leo. Both yellow. Two in the view.
Faint and well away, 10x. To the S.
Neat system. A yellow-white, B blue, much dimmer. South. Wide. Beside 83 Leo. Two in the view.
D, far afield east, very wide. Brighter than B! About 90° from AB angle. White, maybe blue white.
Very cool. Tight. Equilateral triangle. B faint. Fantastic colours at 217x! Yellow and red. Sparse field.
C, aka SAO 157112, is brighter than B. To the N. Fantastic colours again, A yellow; C blue.
Contrasting brightness. Wide. Pretty at low power. Main is white or pale yellow. Companion: white.
Lots going on! A triad shape, close faint pair in the middle. A is to the south. Slightly warmer colour.
Extremely faint, spotted at 139x. Right angle to A and B. Blue-white. Near HD 109875.
D was very faint to the NE. Further out from A than E. Blue-white.
West (opposite C, a right-angle again). Fairly bright. Tiny bit closer to A than the D star. Blue-white.
F brightest of all the members, to the SE. Slightly further from A than D. Blue-white.
Colourful pair. Orange and blue. Pleasingly close at 78x. Lovely.
Main very white blue, partner pale yellow green? Fairly close. Easy to separate at 40x Nice at 48x!
Not far from open cluster Collinder 256. WSW. Pale yellow, both.
Fainter than the eastern triangle stars including TYC 1989-0807 1. Shown as single star in PSA.
To the S. Wide pair, about double AB. Yellow and orange. Within open cluster Collinder 256.
A star further along, more to the east, making a hockey stick with A and C, same brightness as C.
A nice wide colourful double. Yellow is the primary and white-blue is the secondary.
Nearly equal stars. Maybe orange. And white or yellow. Nice. Quite wide at 48x but attractive.
Extremely wide at medium power. 32-33 Com. Orange and blue. To the NE.
C star is dim grey or yellow. A and C might be opposite edges of field of view at very low power!
In a hook shape of stars. Tight pair. Yellow-white  and orange-red. Challenging. Near NGC 4762.
Beside iota Boo. Two in the view. Nice double. Pale yellow and very pale blue?
Beside kappa Boo. Two in the view. Main pale yellow; companion medium pale orange.
Yellow and pale blue-green. Wide. Easy at 48x. ENE.
At 54x, a wide pair. Primary pale yellow or white. Companion quite dim. White? South.
Split at 145x. Both white. Angle of tight pair almost same A and the pair.
NW. Nice. Nearly equal brightness. White or yellow and orange. Surrounded by doubles.
Very tight. Large aperture and good seeing needed. C east of B.
Use binoculars! Extremely wide. White, bright; pale orange. NW.
Even further away but so dim a telescope is needed. WNW.
A nice pair in a 100mm at 55x. Pleasing, tight. Equally bright. Identical in colour: pale yellow.
Requires aperture greater than 90mm. Near Zeta 1 and 2 Coronae Borealis. E of A.
Wide, equal brightness. Orange and blue. C is due E of A. Fainter than zeta CrB.
Dim. C and D are inline and are very close to each other. Likely merged together.
B medium-bright star immediately west, very close, almost touching primary! Beige and pale blue.
Nice double star. Similar magnitudes. Pretty tight. White; pale orange. Oriented NE to SW.
Faint. Very wide. Nearly due E of A.
Dimmer. Extraordinarily wide. To the SW, beyond B.
Colourful stars. A is yellow with a hint orange while B is white. B is NW. Nice triple. Interesting field.
Wide pair, easily separated. Opposite B. The C attendant is in an arc of stars. Serpens Caput.
Grafias. Very low through high power. AB is super-tight. Pale gold both. Big 'scope and 200x?
Colourful stars. NE of A. Bright stars. C is easy split, at low power. C is orange.
aka Alya. Identical stars, like eyes. Tight. A nice double, white stars. Serpens Cauda. ESE.
Slightly fainter but much further out. NE. White and yellow.
Lovely. A brilliant shimmering orange star with pale blue companion. Relatively tight at 217x.
D obvious in good conditions. To the NE. White. Comparatively far away.
A and B are Identical. Exact same brightness and colour. Both white. South.
Dim, to the SE, and about 5 times the AB separation.
Very tight. Switch from low power to high power. ESE. Both white.
16 and 17 Draconis might well be a binocular target. Similar colours and brightness. Nice. South.
Possible beyond the light grasp of binoculars or a small telescope. To the SE.
aka Dragon's Eyes. Wide. Same brightness. One is white; the other a hint of yellow. Very good.
Wide pair. Surprisingly. Main bright yellow; companion dark yellow or yellow with a hint of orange.
Dim and twice the separation. Right angle. C is nearly due E of A.
Nice. Wide. Nearly equal colour and brightness. Not very colourful...  SW.
Wide pair, C is to the SE. Surprisingly close to Ursa Minor.
Dim close-in companion. Due N. Beside Wild Duck Cluster.
The stars looked yellow and blue. Wide. S.
Tight pair to the north. This pair is the same colour, white.
The Double Double. Tim Horton Star! :-) Easy in binoculars. Can you see naked eye?! White.
Tight pair to the south. Slightly different colours. Subtle. 90° angle to AB alignment.
Faint. Bright, east of F. Easily seen at 226x. Pale yellow.
Very faint. Between AB and CD. Closer to AB and eastward. Use averted. Pale yellow.
Very faint. Between AB and CD. Westward. Brighter than F. Pale yellow.
Close at 17x but wide at 71x. Primary brilliant white with hint of yellow. Secondary looks green.
No trouble at 78x. Blue-white? To the NW.
Blue-white? To the NE. This whole multi-star system is not far from the Ring Nebula.
Very faint companion very close to the primary. Visible in large 'scope. Orange or yellow.
Nice wide double. Classic colours: pale yellow and pale blue. Near the Ring Nebula. To the N.
Very faint and far from primary. To the NW.
Pretty. South. Yellow and orange at lower power. Interesting. Near open cluster NGC 6709.
Very interesting pair. Hard to get colours. Bright one seemed a dark yellow; companion looks red.
Nice pair. Almost equal in magnitude. The brighter one is a pale blue; fainter star is pale yellow.
Two gold stars, equally coloured, equally bright. Easily split at 145x. Beside triple HR 7311.
Very faint. Far away to the SE. May be referred to as HD 179957 and HR 7293.
Nearly equal. White and orange. Almost east-west. Lots of faint stars. Attractive at 48x.
The C and D stars popped at 226x. C to the north.
The C and D stars popped at 226x. D to the NE.
The curious star to the far west.
The A star is highly variable, may be dimmer than B. Pale orange and red. SW.
Close. SE. Both light gold. Almost equal brightness. B is slightly fainter than A. Pretty system.
Ay carumba! Very wide. To the SW. Rich field. Surrounded by many faint stars.
Use a detailed atlas or powerful software to identify field stars from official companions. Very wide.
Use atlas or software to identify field stars from official companions. Very wide. Due W.
Use atlas or software to identify field stars from official companions. Very wide. SW.
Use atlas or software to identify field stars from official companions. Very wide. SW.
Use atlas or software to identify field stars from official companions. Wide. W.
Use atlas or software to identify field stars from official companions. Close. SW.
Use atlas or software to identify field stars from official companions. Tight. Faint. SW.
Use atlas or software to identify field stars from official companions. Wide. Faint. W.
Use atlas or software to identify field stars from official companions. Wide. Faint. W.
In a hockey stick, in the blade. Main was a touch brighter than B. Wide. WSW. White and orange.
Obvious. Bright star yellow. B blue? Nearly equal brightness. Oriented nearly perfectly east-west.
Nearly equal. Part of a triangle, at north apex. Very tight, blue-white stars. Near Coathanger.
Very wide. SE. Similar brightness to AB.
Fantastic. Unequal stars in brightness and colour. White and orange. Classic! Near HLM 23.
WNW. Wide at 55x. Orange and blue. Or green? Unequal. Interesting. Near epsilon Sge.
NNW. Tight. Primary yellow-white, partner orange-yellow. Interesting. Low and high power.
C is yellow with a touch of orange. To the SW!
Harder. Grey? D is beyond C. Surrounded by other doubles.
Within open cluster IC 1396. In Elephant Trunk. Wow! White-yellow; companion SW yellow-orange.
The companion to the north, D, the bright one, slightly further, is dull yellow.
SSW. Nearly equal brightness stars, whitish in colour. Near some close colourful stars.
Tight. Main is light yellow. At low power partner looks blue. Pretty, near a loose gaggle of stars.
Very faint start to the south-west, well away.
S. Very wide pair, wide even at 36x. Yellow and blue. Assess variable brightness while here.
ESE. White and orange. Many magnitudes different. Very close together. A neat system!
The C star is dimmer and to the north-west. Bluish.
C is south-west. Yellow-blue. Do not get distracted by binocular double with alpha 2.
Use binoculars! Very wide. Bright yellow and bright blue stars. To the W.
Flanking. SE. Dark blue. They form an isosceles triangle.
Two equal pale blue white stars. WSW.
NW. A and B are blue-ish. Equal brightness. Faint. Near multi-star system Rotanev.
Blue-ish. C slightly fainter than A and B. South-west of B.
Very faint. Flanking, to the north.
Bright yellow gold pair of stars, fairly tight at 77x. West.
NNW. White and orange. Equal. Stunning. Near a faint double. Two in the view.
Easy in a large 'scope. C to the north-east. Bright yellow and light yellow. Hints of green?
Both white? Or pale yellow? B to the south. Slightly dimmer than A. Near double HR 8588.
C was further south of B, slightly east, much dimmer. Orange!
D was brighter than C, south-east of B, and blue.
E, well away to the SW, pale orange, dimmer than B.
Dimmer still. And well away from B, same direction, but not as far as E.
Bright star, blue-white. B might look purple!? B much fainter. Cool! Shown as single star in PSA.
Incredible. Wide. A, orange, B, blue. In a rich field. May not be obvious. Due E.
Forms a spire. Well away to the north-west. Fainter.
Opposite C from the B star. Fainter still.
A little Albireo. Lovely light gold primary and a wide blue companion. Almost equal brightness. E.
Much fainter and much further away. To the NW.
Wow! Burnt yellow and dull orange. Close, to the NW.
Faint and wide. Between B and G. Due W of A.
D star to the N. Faint.
E star to the south-east. Blue. In-line with A and B.
To the west. Faint. Orange.
G star to the west of A and south of F. White.
H star far to the north.
Faint and wide. NE.
Faint and wide.
Wide, easy, low power. Nice yellow and blue. B south. Faint 3rd star. Shown as single star in PSA.
Equal in brightness. Citrus-orange and pale or straw-yellow. Binoculars? Near NGC 752.
Faint. Much closer. East.
Further out from B star. Nearly due W of B.
A close pair of yellow (A) and blue (BC) stars, like a miniature Albireo. Beautiful.
Wide pair. Yellow and blue. Wow. NE.
B is bright star to the east of A. Nearly the same magnitude. Wide. Yellow and pale yellow.
ENE. Bright stars. The main is yellow. The companion is slightly redder.
Very faint and very tight. E of B.
Decent star hop from iota. White and orange. Very close! SW-NE. AB (WDS D 2) are <0.5".
Outlier. The D star was to the south-south-east. 10 times the AC sep. Slightly dimmer than C. Nice!
Equal. Wide. ESE. Yellow and blue.
Bright primary and delicate dim star. B is east. Pale yellow and white.
Interesting. Yellow and orange? Blue? delicate. Not far from Mira. SW.
Faint star to the north-east.
Same magnitude and colour. Yellow-white. Easy to split at 52x. They look like moth eyes!
Dim and very far away, to the east.
Faint. Interesting field stars. B is slightly dimmer and nearly due south. Pale blue both.
Amazing colours. Wide pair. NNE. Easy target in binoculars. Pale orange. B is aquamarine.
Yellow and blue and beautiful! SW.
aka Atik. Tight. A is pale yellow. Near triple HD 24601.
Faintest of all. NW.
A pair, dim, to the south. D and E stars. D is closer. Hard to get colours, orange?
A pair, dim, to the south. D and E stars. Hard to get colours, blue?
Miram. Light orange with blue-green. NW.
Grey. To the W. Same distance as F.
Blue-white. Beyond B. Well away
Dull yellow. Same distance as CD. Nearly due N.
Grey. Same distance as F. D is the "inner" star while C is the "outer."
